Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Algorithms for Group Isomorphism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Symmetry reduces large complex systems to manageable quantities of information. Identifying those symmetries and understanding their structure helps to solve a wide range of problems, from improving engineering tasks to disrupting the mechanisms of disease. The century-old problem of deciding whether two sets of symmetries have the same structure is known today as the Group Isomorphism Problem. This problem is fundamental to both computational algebra and computational complexity, and has implications for fields as diverse as material science, particle physics, and chemistry. The primary goal of this project is to develop significantly better approaches to testing isomorphism of finite groups of symmetries. It supports a new multidisciplinary collaboration between researchers at four universities, including students and early-career mathematicians and computer scientists.

The Group Isomorphism Problem asks for an algorithm to decide whether two finite groups are equivalent. Both the problem itself, and the techniques designed to improve upon it, have implications for other computational problems, including the better-known problems of Graph Isomorphism and P versus NP. Our team's approach goes beyond existing static recursions such as working sequentially down a derived or lower central series. Using a new dynamic strategy we prioritize the optimal stages of the problem, thereby improving the performance of later stages. To achieve this we are investigating the use of nonassociative rings, spectral sequences, modular representation theory, and p-local cohomology. We are also inspecting recently developed data structures in computational algebra that seem well-suited to our approach, as well as investigating applications to geometric complexity theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Symmetry reduces large complex systems to manageable quantities of information. Identifying those symmetries and understanding their structure helps to solve a wide range of problems, from improving engineering tasks to disrupting the mechanisms of disease. The century-old problem of deciding whether two sets of symmetries have the same structure is known today as the Group Isomorphism Problem. This problem is fundamental to both computational algebra and computational complexity, and has implications for fields as diverse as material science, particle physics, and chemistry. This award supported a multidisciplinary collaboration between researchers at four universities, including students and early-career mathematicians and computer scientists.

In this project, the investigators identified the Tensor Isomorphism Problem as a central obstacle to further progress on Group Isomorphism, which in turn is a key obstacle to further progress on the well-studied problem of Graph Isomorphism. The project showed that Tensor Isomorphism has wide applicability, being equivalent to dozens of problems from different areas of research, including quantum mechanics, cryptography, and machine learning. The team used Tensor Isomorphism as a building block to prove two first-of-their-kind results on Group Isomorphism, making progress on a long-standing conjecture about what groups should be the hardest cases of this problem. The team developed a new algorithmic paradigm for Tensor Isomorphism and Group Isomorphism, in a way that combined their previous results and expertise from multiple disciplines. The project also resulted in software implementations of some of these ideas, improving the state of the art both in theory and in practice.

This project led to training and research experiences for two PhD students, one undergraduate student, and one high school student at University of Colorado Boulder (the collaborative award for the same project at Colorado State University included an additional three graduate students). The research and context of this award also provided the necessary impetus and backdrop for an international conference on tensors, organized by the project team, that brought together researchers from mathematics, physics, and computer science.
